Content.Name: Composer of the Week
Content.Description: Franz Schubert (1797-1828): 1/5

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain presents Ars Nova at the Stoense Summer Music Festival 2005, plus music by Shostakovich, Scriabin, Górecki, Penderecki and Janácek

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain continues Through the Night with works by Dvorák, Puccini, Mozart, Telemann, Pachelbel, Scarlatti, Piazzolla, Schubert and Vivaldi

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain ends Through the Night with works by CPE Bach, Mozart, Fanny Mendelssohn, Tallis, JS Bach, Mozetich, Haydn, Janácek, Dvorák, Billings and Svendsen

Content.Name: Morning on 3
Content.Description: Penny Gore continues with more of Mozart's early symphonies, and explores music at the theatre during the French Baroque

Content.Name: CD Masters
Content.Description: Rob Cowan features Handel's Messiah and other sacred works, plus recordings by Fritz Kreisler

Content.Name: Composer of the Week
Content.Description: Jean Sibelius (1865-1957): 1/5

Content.Name: Lunchtime Concert
Content.Description: Joyce DiDonato and Julius Drake perform songs linked with the romantic city of Venice, live from Wigmore Hall in London

Content.Name: Making Tracks
Content.Description: CBBC's Angellica Bell and Adrian Dickson present the programme for younger listeners

Content.Name: Stage and Screen
Content.Description: Sir Charles Mackerras at 80: Edward Seckerson talks to Sir Charles at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, about his life in opera

Content.Name: In Tune
Content.Description: Sean Rafferty presents a selection of music and keeps us up to date with what's happening in the arts world

Content.Name: Get Carter!
Content.Description: The Elliott Carter tribute continues with the BBC Symphony Orchestra at the Barbican Hall, London

Content.Name: Night Waves
Content.Description: Isabel Hilton presents the arts and ideas magazine, including news of the winner of the 2005 TS Eliot Prize for Poetry and an interview with writer Michael Moorcock

Content.Name: Late Junction
Content.Description: Verity Sharp presents music from guitarist John Fahey; the improvising duo of Clive Bell and Sylvia Hallett, and composer Thomas Adès with his 1992 piano piece Darknesse Visible

Content.Name: Composer of the Week
Content.Description: Franz Schubert (1797-1828): 2/5

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain presents Dag Wirén Chamber Music, plus pieces from Biber, Corelli, Hempenius, Schubert, Mozart, Infante and Klami

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Through the Night continues as Jonathan Swain presents music by Moniuszko, Ravel, Bacewicz and Bizet

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Through the Night concludes as Jonathan Swain presents music by Montsalvatge, Villa-Lobos, Arriaga, Cavalli, Salmenhaara, Knipper, Ibert and Grieg

Content.Name: Composer of the Week
Content.Description: Jean Sibelius (1865-1957): 2/5

Content.Name: Lunchtime Concert
Content.Description: Celebrating Mozart: 1/4

Content.Name: Voices
Content.Description: Iain Burnside talks to American composer and raconteur William Bolcom about the art of songwriting, his experiences as a pupil of Milhaud, and the stars of the New York artistic scene

Content.Name: Get Carter!
Content.Description: The BBC Symphony Orchestra's Carter homage ends with three works that exploit the spatial possibilities of groups of musicians in the concert hall

Content.Name: New Generation Artists
Content.Description: Verity Sharp presents a series featuring Radio 3's New Generation artists; with violinist Alina Ibragimova and pianist Cedric Tiberghien performing Beethoven's Sonata for violin and piano in G

Content.Name: Night Waves
Content.Description: Susan Hitch and guests discuss the life and work of HL Mencken; newspaper man, critic, iconoclast and one of America's most influential writers of the 20th Century

Content.Name: Late Junction
Content.Description: Verity Sharp introduces music from Egyptian percussionist Mahmoud Fadl and vocalist Salwa Abou Greisha, and a song from Robert Wyatt's 1975 album Ruth is Stranger than Richard

Content.Name: Composer of the Week
Content.Description: Franz Schubert (1797-1828): 3/5

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain features the Ensemble Zimmermann, plus music from Verdi, Pejacevic, Zemlinsky, Falla, Albéniz, Vaughan Williams, Weelkes and JS Bach

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain continues the programme with music by Françaix, Riisager, Gesualdo and Haydn

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain concludes the programme with music by d'India, Liadov, Saint-Saëns, Binelli, Gershwin, Molique, Mozart and JS Bach

Content.Name: Composer of the Week
Content.Description: Jean Sibelius (1865-1957): 3/5

Content.Name: Lunchtime Concert
Content.Description: Celebrating Mozart: 2/4

Content.Name: Choral Evensong
Content.Description: Live from Bath Abbey

Content.Name: In Tune
Content.Description: Andrew Parrot joins Sean Rafferty to discuss the Mozart 250th Birthday Celebration Weekend

Content.Name: Night Waves
Content.Description: Philip Dodd explores the enduring fascination with the American Civil War, talking to guests including the acclaimed novelist EL Doctorow

Content.Name: Late Junction
Content.Description: Verity Sharp's choices include the string duo of Djeli Moussa Diawara and Bob Brozman; ambient electronic music from Brian Eno and Harold Budd; and Arvo Pärt's Cantus in memory of Benjamin Britten

Content.Name: Composer of the Week
Content.Description: Franz Schubert (1797-1828): 4/5

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain presents music by JS Bach, Liszt, Widor, Bruckner, Sibelius, Beethoven, Glazunov, Mozart, Haydn and Martinu

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain continues the programme featuring works by Holländer, Françaix, Saint-Saëns, Desprez, Mussorgsky and Chopin

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain concludes the programme featuring works by Kreisler, Alfvén, Moss, Ravel, Mozart, Telemann and Respighi

Content.Name: Composer of the Week
Content.Description: Jean Sibelius (1865-1957): 4/5

Content.Name: Lunchtime Concert
Content.Description: Celebrating Mozart: 3/4

Content.Name: Brian Kay's Light Programme
Content.Description: Brian Kay plays some light classics, including Louis Levy and his Gaumont British Symphony with a selection from Hollywood Hotel

Content.Name: Performance on 3
Content.Description: Live concert from the refurbished, reborn Glasgow City Halls, the new home of the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra

Content.Name: Twenty Minutes
Content.Description: Poem for a Concert Hall: To mark the opening of the City Halls, Glasgow's poet laureate Liz Lochhead reads her new specially composed poem to celebrate the changing face of the city

Content.Name: Performance on 3
Content.Description: The live concert from the new home of the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra continues, with the focus on Stravinsky's The Firebird

Content.Name: Night Waves
Content.Description: Paul Allen is joined by Martin Rowson to discuss A Cock and Bull Story, Michael Winterbottom's adaptation of Laurence Sterne's 18th century novel The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman

Content.Name: Late Junction
Content.Description: Featuring Ellen Fullman's music for the Long String Instrument, traditional Balkan sounds from Dusan Radetic and Giacinto Scelsi's 1963 work for orchestra, Hymnos

Content.Name: Composer of the Week
Content.Description: Franz Schubert (1797-1828): 5/5

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain features The Romanian National Radio Orchestra in Bucharest, plus works by Jadin, Beethoven, Brahms and Reicha

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain features music by Dvorák, Chopin, Holst, Schubert, Khachaturian, Debussy and Strauss

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain ends the programme with music by Weber, Monteverdi, Ravel, Mozart, Verdi, Palestrina, Fodor, Chausson and Dvorák

Content.Name: Composer of the Week
Content.Description: Jean Sibelius (1865-1957): 5/5

Content.Name: Lunchtime Concert
Content.Description: Celebrating Mozart: 4/4

Content.Name: Jazz Legends
Content.Description: Julian Joseph in conversation with the American jazz theorist, educator and musician George Russell

Content.Name: Performance on 3
Content.Description: The Scottish Chamber Orchestra makes its debut appearance in the new City Halls concert hall in Glasgow, presenting a programme with a Parisian flavour

Content.Name: Twenty Minutes
Content.Description: The Scottish Adverb: Ian McMillan celebrates the opening of the City Halls in Glasgow in the company of writer and poet, Professor Robert Crawford

Content.Name: Performance on 3
Content.Description: The Scottish Chamber Orchestra continues its debut appearance in the new City Halls concert hall in Glasgow, with works by Mozart and Chevalier de Saint-George

Content.Name: Night Waves
Content.Description: Matthew Sweet with another edition of the arts and ideas programme

Content.Name: Mixing It
Content.Description: Mark Russell and Robert Sandall present a unique mix of musical styles and influences

Content.Name: Jazz on 3
Content.Description: Jez Nelson presents a special tribute to a true great of British contemporary music, guitarist Derek Bailey, who died on Christmas Day

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain features the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra at Davies Symphony Hall, plus music by Kraus, Röntgen, Brahms, Dobrzynski, Goldmark and Sweelinck

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain continues the programme with works by Corelli, Frescobaldi, Lassus, Kogoj and Parac

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain ends the programme with music from Vivaldi, Telemann, Rubinstein, Tchaikovsky, Beethoven, Paganini, Reinecke, Henderson and Mozetich

Content.Name: Morning on 3
Content.Description: Martin Handley presents works by Sullivan, Janácek, Couperin and Mozart

Content.Name: CD Review
Content.Description: Andrew McGregor plays some of this month's newest releases

Content.Name: The Early Music Show
Content.Description: Catherine Bott introduces a live concert of Early Music from the Recital Hall of the newly opened City Halls in Glasgow

Content.Name: Discovering Music
Content.Description: Music and Meaning in the Magic Flute: As a prelude to the opera Live from the Met, Charles Hazlewood leads a workshop in which he explores the music and meaning of Mozart's great singspiel

Content.Name: World Routes
Content.Description: A concert to mark the reopening of the Fruitmarket, one of the three venues in Glasgow's refurbished City Halls

Content.Name: Jazz Line-up
Content.Description: Claire Martin presents the programme live from the refurbished City Halls in Glasgow, with the BBC Big Band conducted by Barry Forgie, featuring guest saxophonist Nigel Hitchcock

Content.Name: Jazz Record Requests
Content.Description: Request your favourite jazz cut by E mail: jazz

Content.Name: Jazz File
Content.Description: Ronnie Scott's: George Melly explores the history of the world's best known jazz club

Content.Name: Opera on 3
Content.Description: Die Zauberflöte: Presented from New York by Margaret Juntwait, live from the Met

Content.Name: The Met Opera Quiz
Content.Description: Thor Eckert puts listeners' questions to Carolyn Abbate, Alan Wagner and Willie Anthony Waters

Content.Name: Opera on 3
Content.Description: Die Zauberflöte: The second Act of Mozart's magical opera, live from the New York Metropolitan Opera

Content.Name: The Verb
Content.Description: Ian McMillan presents the weekly magazine about language

Content.Name: Pre-Hear
Content.Description: Featuring Steve Reich's Octet from 1979, with Nurit Tilles, Edward Niemann, Virgil Blackwell, Mort Silver, Shem Guibbory, Robert Chausow, Ruth Siegler and Chris Finckel

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain presents music by Toch, Mahler, Zarebski, Chopin, Brahms, Handel, JS Bach, Franck, Contant and d'India

Content.Name: Through the Night
Content.Description: Jonathan Swain concludes Through the Night with works by JS Bach, Vivaldi, Haydn, Berwald, Dupré, Panufnik, Dett, Guion, Cage and Dohnányi

Content.Name: Morning on 3
Content.Description: Martin Handley features works by Donizetti, Schubert, Balakirev and Mozart

Content.Name: The Cowan Collection
Content.Description: Rob Cowan presents music by Delibes, Handel, Schmelzer, Nielsen, Strauss, Shostakovich, Weill, Mozart, Victoria, Dohnányi, Stenhammar and Gabrieli

Content.Name: Private Passions
Content.Description: Michael Berkeley's guest is writer and poet Michael Symmons Roberts

Content.Name: The Early Music Show
Content.Description: Lucie Skeaping presents a programme of music by the Slovenian composer, Jacobus Handl, also known as Jacobus Gallus

Content.Name: Sunday Gala
Content.Description: Stephanie Hughes introduces a concert from the 2005 Mozartwoche in Salzburg

Content.Name: 3 For All
Content.Description: Louise Fryer introduces more listeners' requests, including Elgar's last major chamber work; his piano quintet

Content.Name: Music Matters
Content.Description: Tom Service talks to Argentine composer Osvaldo Golijov, whose La Pasión Según San Marcos gets its UK premiere at the Barbican as part of two concerts focusing on his work

Content.Name: The Choir
Content.Description: Aled Jones recruits choral conductor Peter Broadbent as talent scout for a look at some of the most exciting choirs emerging from the UK and Europe

Content.Name: Drama on 3
Content.Description: Hold My Breath, by Ryan Craig

Content.Name: Sunday Feature
Content.Description: Desperately Seeking Mozart: Paul Robertson sets out in search of the real Mozart, speaking to academics who have dedicated their life's work to paring away the mythology

Content.Name: Andy Kershaw
Content.Description: Playing what they like to call 'soil music', this is a Radio 3 debut for the Famous Potatoes, with their old time hybrid of western swing, bluegrass, folk and Cajun music
